node.Title: Southern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook 2015-16: November update
node.Body: An updated Southern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook has been released, covering South Australia and Tasmania.

node.Title: Raising the bar on risk reduction policy and planning
node.Body: Hazard Note 13 is an overview of the Governance and institutional knowledge cluster of research projects, which are tackling some of the most challenging policy, governance and communication issues confronting emergency management.

node.Title: Southern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook 2017
node.Body: With most of Australia experiencing a combination of above average temperatures and below average rainfall over winter, large parts of the country face above normal bushfire potential for the fire season.

node.Title: Assessing Australia's resilience to natural hazards
node.Body: Hazard Note 39 reports on research that has developed an index of disaster resilience, designed to help meet the challenges of Australia's natural hazards.

node.Title: Southern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook 2018-19: November
node.Body: Above normal fire potential remains across large parts of southern Australia. Rain in areas of eastern Australia during spring, while welcome, was not enough to recover from the long term dry conditions. Wet conditions currently being experienced across coastal New South Wales will help, but it will not take long once heat and dry conditions return for vegetation to dry out.

node.Title: Mental health needs of first responders
node.Body: Hazard Note 56 focuses on new research initiated by Beyond Blue in collaboration with the CRC on a national survey of the mental health and wellbeing of police and emergency services personnel.

node.Title: Communicating for maximum comprehension
node.Body: Natural hazards raise considerable uncertainty and anxiety, and providing the community with information that is designed to instil specific preparation and response behaviours is important for emergency services. Hazard Note 57 details examples of principles to follow to maximise comprehension of warning messages.

node.Title: Black Saturday ten years on – what did we discover?
node.Body: This Hazard Note highlights the key findings of the Bushfire CRC research after the 2009 Black Saturday bushfires, focusing on fire behaviour, human behaviour, and building and planning issues.

node.Title: Conflicting cues with emergency warnings impacts protective action
node.Body: Emergency services have suspected that conflicting cues exist when warning messages are issued, but this is the first research to offer empirical evidence of the impact of conflicting cues and how they influence public behaviour in Australia.

node.Title: Making diversity and inclusion the new normal in emergency services
node.Body: Hazard Note 60 explains research findings on diversity and inclusion in emergency management, highlighting key characteristics that enable diverse and inclusive organisations such as being strategic, collaborative, outward thinking, future focused, and empowerment of individuals.

node.Title: Pyroconvective interactions and spot fire dynamics
node.Body: Hazard Note 61 details pioneering research that is developing the first, two-dimensional fire simulation model that can operate in faster than real time, while incorporating intrinsic, fire line dynamics.

node.Title: Northern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook 2019
node.Body: What is the fire outlook across northern Australia for the bushfire season? The Northern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook 2019 has all the details.

node.Title: Australian Seasonal Bushfire Outlook: September - November 2020
node.Body: The 2020/21 fire season will be driven by vastly different climate drivers than the previous two fire seasons. With a La Niña ALERT now active, large areas of eastern and northern Australia are expecting wetter than average conditions through spring

node.Title: On the frontline: the roles of pharmacists in disasters
node.Body: Hazard Note 78 presents PhD research that identifies the different roles that pharmacists can play during disasters.

node.Title: Emergency warning messages: how do community members comprehend them?
node.Body: Hazard Note 79 outlines opportunities for emergency services agencies to improve their communication and messaging.

node.Title: Emergency warning messages: encouraging readiness to act
node.Body: Hazard Note 80 details which types of specific messages encourage community readiness.

node.Title: Emergency warning messages: do colours and icons improve community readiness to act?
node.Body: Hazard Note 81 explores whether colours and icons help to encourage action during emergencies.

node.Title: How to enhance community recovery after disasters
node.Body: Hazard Note 89 presents a new multidimensional, inclusive and systemic guide to enhance community recovery after disasters.

node.Title: Learning lessons from the past with the Inquiries and Reviews Database
node.Body: The Inquiries and Reviews Database holds more than 130 years' worth of emergency and management inquiries, reviews and Royal Commissions conducted in Australia.

node.Title: Australian Seasonal Bushfire Outlook: March - May 2021
node.Body: The influence of La Niña on Australia’s climate has had a pronounced effect on fire potential. More rain than usual in many locations over summer has helped to reduce the fire risk. However, autumn will still see hot and windy days that raise the fire risk in some locations.

node.Title: Improving emergency management teamwork using non-technical skills
node.Body: Hazard Note 92 presents the Emergency Management Non-Technical Skills tool, designed to help emergency management individuals and teams enhance their non-technical skills and strengthen capabilities.

node.Title: Supporting emergency management team performance during emergencies
node.Body: Hazard Note 93 presents the Key Tasks Cognitive Aid, a checklist designed to support state and regional-level emergency management teams during an emergency.

node.Title: Building collaborative emergency management capacity in northern Australia
node.Body: Hazard Note 94 presents research that used consultation and respect to empower Indigenous communities by enhancing capability to better understand emergency management procedures.

node.Title: Lessons from Black Summer: how people experienced the 2019/20 NSW fire season
node.Body: Research in NSW after the 2019-20 fire season highlights the challenges around community expectations of warnings, with many people expecting to receive highly detailed and localised information in near real-time. New communication initiatives such as fire spread prediction maps and Tourist Leave Zone messages, were found to be effective in communicating risk and motivating people to take action.

node.Title: The benefits of strengthening buildings against earthquakes
node.Body: Hazard Note 112 presents evisjustify the cost of strengthening existing buildings to withstand earthquake damage.

node.Title: Understanding what happens when bushfires merge
node.Body: Hazard Note 113 presents new research that used field-scale experiments and drones to track the way that merging fire fronts behave.
